results.title: Priit Parn: selected films
results.brief_description: This tape features three films from the award winning Estonian animation director and political cartoonist, Priit Parn. An artist who uses animation to satirise and parody the old Soviet system and the conflicting outcomes of Perestroika. His films are rich with repetition and allusion, and as with much Eastern European animation, is laden with symbolism. “Time out” follows the antics of a hero cat (produced by Hille Koosk); “Breakfast on the grass” provides a parallel with Manet’s work and reveals bureaucracy at its most malign (produced by Tallinnfilm); “Hotel E” explores the process of Glasnost, using a hotel setting as a metaphor for East and West (produced by Olav Osolin).

results.title: Pride and prejudice. Parts 1 & 2
results.creator_credit: Simon Langton, Sue Birtwistle, Arts Entertainment Network and BBC
results.brief_description: Jane Austen’s famous novel is brought to life in this vibrant, fresh adaptation. Full of energy, the script, performances, sets, locations and costume design are excellent, while the overall production veers away from the formality of previous adaptations. Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle are Darcy and Elizabeth and they are joined by a large and well-known cast including Barbara Leigh Hunt, Alison Steadman, Julia Sawalha and Susannah Harker. The underlying initial tension between Elizabeth and Darcy, develops into love, and their faults; pride on his part and prejudice on hers, blossoms into a deep and lasting mutual respect.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Simon Langton, Sue Birtwistle, Arts Entertainment Network and BBC

results.title: Pretty Penny
results.creator_credit: Shane Luther, Jacinta Stone and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: A light-hearted cautionary tale about human ambitions and moral dilemmas that centres on the relationship between an avaricious coin collector and and a woman who owns a rare coin. Cast: Kestie Morrassi, Shane Luther. (Awards: Sydney Film Festival, 1999; Watch My Shorts Film Festival Melbourne, 1999; Sydney Video & Film Festival, 1999)

results.title: Pretty as a picture: the art of David Lynch
results.creator_credit: Toby Keeler and Fine Cut Presentations
results.brief_description: Using a behind the scenes look at the production of David Lynch’s ‘Lost highway’, this documentary looks at the auteur who brought us ‘Eraserhead’ (307091), ‘Elephant man’ (302534), ‘Blue velvet (302912), and the television series ‘Twin peaks’. He discusses his inspiration, impressions of his first film, and his drive for creative expression. Interviews are presented with actors who have starred in Lynchs’ films, relatives, and production crew. They include; Bill Pullman, Patricia Arquette, Mel Brooks, Jack Frisk, Barry Gifford, Jennifer Lynch, Jack Nance, Mary Sweeney and Dean Stockwell.

results.title: Prague 2000
results.brief_description: This tour of the beautiful city of Prague in the Czech Republic presents the rich history and full range of museums, churches and palaces of Bohemian kings. Beginning in the Old Town Square, we travel across the famous Charles Bridge to Mala Strana and Hradcany to visit all of the famous tourist destinations within the city and along the Vltava River. Highlights include St Nicholas Church, Franz Kafka’s house and museum, the Jewish Quarter, Prague Castle, the Infant Jesus of Prague, Dvorak Hall and Prague Zoo.

results.title: Powaqqatsi: Life in transformation [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Godfrey Reggio, Lawrence Taub, Mel Lawrence and Golan-Globus
results.brief_description: A feast for the eyes and ears - “Powaqqatsi: life in transformation” is a spellbinding look at life on our planet from the depths of an iron ore mine in Brazil, to the commotion of city life in the concrete jungle of Hong Kong. Featuring hypnotic music by renowned composer Philip Glass, this is a truly amazing and totally original experience in modern cinema.

results.title: Fantasia [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Walt Disney and Walt Disney Productions
results.brief_description: An animated feast of music and visuals. Featuring a soundtrack of classical music, including selections by Bach, Tchaikovsky and Moussorgsky, the film weds animated narratives to the famous musical pieces. “Fantasia” includes one of Disney’s most loved sequences, “The Sorcerer’s Apprentice”. At its best the film’s animation remains magical and visually breath-taking.

constellations_other.name: Circling expanded cinema
constellations_other.description: Explore how expanded cinema like Lis Rhodes' Light Music connects to film composers, experimental materials and virtual reality.

results.title: Fat pizza
results.creator_credit: Paul Fenech, Tanith Carroll, Fat Pizza and Village Roadshow Pictures
results.brief_description: This Australian comedy, based on the SBS television show “Pizza”, has an irreverent anarchic flavour that is certain to (intentionally) offend. Pauly (Paul Fenech) is a pizza delivery boy who works for the explosively bad-tempered Bobo (Johnny Boxer); Pauly’s other main occupation is to drive about in his souped-up car, with its blaring sub-woofer stereo; meanwhile his friends Sleek (Paul Nakad), and Davo (Jabba) similarly cruise around in their own customised vehicle, encountering violent cops and sexually eager women. Fans of the series will recognise the vigour with which writer Fenech attacks sacred cows of Australian culture - principally, but not exclusively, the young male Lebanese/Australian racial stereotype - whilst applying a thick layer of infantile machismo and t&a humour. Certainly not to the taste of all, but quite original and daring in both concept and execution. Cast also incudes Annalise Braakensiek with cameos by Merv Hughes, Tim Ferguson, Jeff Fenech, Shane Porteous, Red Symons, Bernard King and Kamahl.
